comments:
Using 3.2M4 on Win XP

I am not sure what is causing the InterruptedException but I do seem to find quite a few in my log.

What sort of operation are you doing?
Wish I really knew.  Dumping more info on the job might have helped.  But I think I was performing some SVN (Subversion) operations like a commit or update.

I was able to reproduce this on linux (RCP-3.1-GTK). Stacktrace is almost the same (see below). As for the kind of work.. I'm fighting with the other problem - sometimes the Progress view has jobs (phantoms?) with "Waiting" and "Cancelled" state. They still appear under not clear conditions.

So, I just started a job, canceled it, then started again. Also tried this when Progress view is opened, and when it is closed. Job priority is BUILD; isUser = true. Before job is scheduled, all jobs of this family was canceled using JobManagerMan.cancel(MyJob.MY_JOB); and then JobManager.join(...).

(trace)
java.lang.InterruptedException: sleep interrupted
  at java.lang.Thread.sleep(Native Method)
  at org.eclipse.ui.internal.progress.ProgressMonitorFocusJobDialog$12.run(ProgressMonitorFocusJobDialog.java:386)
  at org.eclipse.swt.custom.BusyIndicator.showWhile(BusyIndicator.java:69)
  at org.eclipse.ui.internal.progress.ProgressMonitorFocusJobDialog.show(ProgressMonitorFocusJobDialog.java:381)
...

You are getting this because the job you are running is throwing the InterruptedException and I log them - the problem here is that you are not getting any useful information. I'll make up a test plug-in and we can see if we can do any better.

Talking to John the best approach as that we should not log this exception at all. The InterruptedException occurs whenever a sync exec occurs from another Thread to make sure that the UI Thread is not deadlocked.

See UILockListener.
